title: How to Make a Cardboard Clock

steps.headline: Make a circle out of cardboard.
steps.description: You can use corrugated cardboard or poster board. Use a compass or string and pencil to draw a circle of the desired size. Cut the cardboard using a craft knife or scissors.

steps.headline: Decorate the cardboard to make a clock face.
steps.description: Add numbers using a marker, crayon, pen, or stickers. Add other decorations as desired.

steps.headline: Add hands to complete the clock.
steps.description: You can make the hands any shape. An arrow shape or pointed line works well. The hands can be any material, but they should be strong enough to withstand being moved around the clock face. Attach the hands to the clock face with a brass fastener.

steps.headline: Teach preschoolers basic concepts of time.
steps.description: Preschoolers usually aren't able to  read an analog clock, but they are aware that it is a tool to measure the passage of time. Teach preschoolers the concept of "big hand, little hand." Show them when the clock hands are in a specific position, it's time for a certain event. For example, when "the big hand is on the 12 and the little hand is on the 5," it's time for supper. As the child gains an understanding of how to read a clock, progress to terms like minute and hour hand.

steps.headline: Teach school-age kids how to read an analog clock.
steps.description: Generally, children should be able to read hour and half-hours on a clock by the time they are in kindergarten. Most children are able to understand the passage of time, and how it relates to day and night by third grade.

methods.name: Making a Working Clock Out of Cardboard

steps.headline: Obtain a clock movement.
steps.description:
Battery-powered clock mechanisms are available online or at craft stores. Usually the clock mechanism comes with hands. If not, you can make clock hands out of cardboard or plastic. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/15\/DSCF0004-%282%29.jpg\/460px-DSCF0004-%282%29.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/15\/DSCF0004-%282%29.jpg\/760px-DSCF0004-%282%29.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":343,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":566.8681318681319,"licensing":"

steps.headline: Make a circle out of cardboard.
steps.description: You can use corrugated cardboard or poster board. Use a compass or string and pencil to draw a circle of the desired size. Cut the cardboard using a craft knife or scissors.

steps.headline: Decorate the cardboard to make a clock face.
steps.description: Add numbers using a marker, crayon, pen, or stickers. Add other decorations as desired.

steps.headline: Make a hole in the center of the clock face.
Insert the mechanism shaft into the hole.
steps.description: Apply the hardware provided in the package according to the instructions.

steps.headline: Add the hands to complete the clock.
Take two rectangles of cardboard and draw right triangles in each of the upper corners.
steps.description: You should have 2 identical pieces of cardboard.

steps.headline: Cut the triangle off the cardboard rectangles.
Cut cardboard rectangles to form the sides and roof of the clock.
Attach the clock face and mechanism to the front of the clock.
Decorate the clock as desired.
steps.description: Add any decorations you want to. You may also want to add a pendulum to complete cuckoo clock effect.

tyn: Needles for hands (as in a real clock hands or needles)
text:
Making a Teaching Clock Make a circle out of cardboard. You can use corrugated cardboard or poster board. Use a compass or string and pencil to draw a circle of the desired size. Cut the cardboard using a craft knife or scissors. Decorate the cardboard to make a clock face. Add numbers using a marker, crayon, pen, or stickers. Add other decorations as desired. Add hands to complete the clock. You can make the hands any shape. An arrow shape or pointed line works well. The hands can be any material, but they should be strong enough to withstand being moved around the clock face. Attach the hands to the clock face with a brass fastener. Teaching Kids to Tell Time Teach preschoolers basic concepts of time. Preschoolers usually aren't able to read an analog clock, but they are aware that it is a tool to measure the passage of time. Teach preschoolers the concept of "big hand, little hand." Show them when the clock hands are in a specific position, it's time for a certain event. For example, when "the big hand is on the 12 and the little hand is on the 5," it's time for supper. As the child gains an understanding of how to read a clock, progress to terms like minute and hour hand. Teach school-age kids how to read an analog clock. Generally, children should be able to read hour and half-hours on a clock by the time they are in kindergarten. Most children are able to understand the passage of time, and how it relates to day and night by third grade. Making a Working Clock Out of Cardboard Obtain a clock movement. Battery-powered clock mechanisms are available online or at craft stores. Usually the clock mechanism comes with hands. If not, you can make clock hands out of cardboard or plastic. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/15\/DSCF0004-%282%29.jpg\/460px-DSCF0004-%282%29.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/15\/DSCF0004-%282%29.jpg\/760px-DSCF0004-%282%29.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":343,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":566.8681318681319,"licensing":"

Image by: Uploader
\nLicense: Creative Commons<\/a>\n<\/p><\/div>"} Make a circle out of cardboard. You can use corrugated cardboard or poster board. Use a compass or string and pencil to draw a circle of the desired size. Cut the cardboard using a craft knife or scissors. Decorate the cardboard to make a clock face. Add numbers using a marker, crayon, pen, or stickers. Add other decorations as desired. Make a hole in the center of the clock face. Insert the mechanism shaft into the hole. Apply the hardware provided in the package according to the instructions. Add the hands to complete the clock. Making a Cardboard Cuckoo Clock Take two rectangles of cardboard and draw right triangles in each of the upper corners. You should have 2 identical pieces of cardboard. Cut the triangle off the cardboard rectangles. Cut cardboard rectangles to form the sides and roof of the clock. Attach the clock face and mechanism to the front of the clock. Decorate the clock as desired. Add any decorations you want to. You may also want to add a pendulum to complete cuckoo clock effect.
sentences: Making a Teaching Clock Make a circle out of cardboard.
You can use corrugated cardboard or poster board.
Use a compass or string and pencil to draw a circle of the desired size.
Cut the cardboard using a craft knife or scissors.
Decorate the cardboard to make a clock face.
Add numbers using a marker, crayon, pen, or stickers.
Add other decorations as desired.
Add hands to complete the clock.
You can make the hands any shape.
An arrow shape or pointed line works well.
The hands can be any material, but they should be strong enough to withstand being moved around the clock face.
Attach the hands to the clock face with a brass fastener.
Teaching Kids to Tell Time Teach preschoolers basic concepts of time.
Preschoolers usually aren't able to  read an analog clock, but they are aware that it is a tool to measure the passage of time.
Teach preschoolers the concept of "big hand, little hand."
Show them when the clock hands are in a specific position, it's time for a certain event.
For example, when "the big hand is on the 12 and the little hand is on the 5," it's time for supper.
As the child gains an understanding of how to read a clock, progress to terms like minute and hour hand.
Teach school-age kids how to read an analog clock.
Generally, children should be able to read hour and half-hours on a clock by the time they are in kindergarten.
Most children are able to understand the passage of time, and how it relates to day and night by third grade.
Making a Working Clock Out of Cardboard Obtain a clock movement.
Battery-powered clock mechanisms are available online or at craft stores.
Usually the clock mechanism comes with hands.
If not, you can make clock hands out of cardboard or plastic.

Cut the cardboard using a craft knife or scissors.
Decorate the cardboard to make a clock face.
Add numbers using a marker, crayon, pen, or stickers.
Add other decorations as desired.
Make a hole in the center of the clock face.
Insert the mechanism shaft into the hole.

Making a Cardboard Cuckoo Clock Take two rectangles of cardboard and draw right triangles in each of the upper corners.
You should have 2 identical pieces of cardboard.
Cut the triangle off the cardboard rectangles.
Cut cardboard rectangles to form the sides and roof of the clock.
Attach the clock face and mechanism to the front of the clock.
Decorate the clock as desired.
Add any decorations you want to.
You may also want to add a pendulum to complete cuckoo clock effect.
